title: Why Budapest, Warsaw and Lithuania split themselves in two
description: Every year, the European Union funnels 50 billion â‚¬ (one third of its total budget) to its poorer regions in the EU as catch-up funds. For many regions this money constitutes an important part of public investments. But because the funds are primarily directed at the poorest regions, regions that get richer receive less money over time. That is why governors of these regions started redrawing region boundaries. This is how EU money flows and provokes statistical gerrymandering, European style.
